p: Clare Heyward has criticized the Moral Equivalence Thesis on the grounds that its implementation would have unacceptable moral consequences for offspring. Yet those endorsing the Moral Equivalence Thesis could respond that they are defending it as an ethical (not political) abstract philosophical principle, and that, additionally, it remains to be discussed what would follow for all-things-considered questions of implementation, especially if that implementation concerns policies and hence would be political. See Clare Heyward, “A Growing Problem? Dealing with Population Increases in Climate Justice,” Ethical Perspectives Vol. 19, No. 4 (2012), pp. 703-732.
